pros: Faculty are the heartbeat of this place.
cons:
I have never seen a business so set on impeding their customers at every turn. Nor have I seen a more dedicated band of employees determined to provide a quality product to their customers in spite of their employers. At every turn the administration sabotages the efforts of the faculty, denies needed resources, and undermines morale in an attempt to wield their power. The reputation and success of OSUIT VisCom was built with thankless hard work, tireless dedication and unrewarded passion. The mismanaged potential and stifled talent in this school ranks as one of the greatest injustices to not only the students but also to the faculty and community. 

Repeatedly, I have seen an easy solution to a recurring problem passed over in order to score political points or fuel a grudge. Consistently I have seen the glaring avoidance of logic in order to apply pressure to those seen as enemies. Routinely I have witnessed the aversion to do what is best for this school in favor of doing what hurts administration’s opponents most.

pros: A Graduate Research Assistant (GRA) must be admitted to and meet the requirements of the Graduate College, be fully admitted to a graduate degree program, enrolled, and be under the supervision of an appropriate graduate faculty member.  GRAs are provided a stipend and their primary responsibilities are to provide general support to the University's research mission.  These responsibilities may or may not relate directly to the student's thesis or dissertation.  Duties of the GRA primarily involve applying and mastering research concepts, practices, or methods of scholarship.  Services provided by a GRA may include: assisting faculty members in a research or creative activity; performing degree-related professional or administrative services that supports research, instruction, professional development, or outreach missions of the University; developing and evaluating instructional materials or curricula; or assuming responsibility for designated scholarly endeavors.

review_title: OSU-OKC is becoming a great place to work!
job_title: Security Officer in Oklahoma City, OK
pros:
The new president of OSU-OKC has really boosted the moral of the staff members and the university is becoming a really great place to work!

cons: - Depending on who you work for, there may be few career opportunities. I work for the Security Department, and there are rarely ever any opportunities that open up within the department. I think some departments, such as Security, Grounds, and Maintenance, may sometimes be stereotyped as employing personnel who aren't very smart, so it can be hard to escape from those departments.

pros:
I've been with OkState for six years. Basically starting out with not much experience I have learned a lot. Benefits have been pretty decent over the past six year. Okstate offers employee incentives for continuing education. They also offer some discounts to attend the university while you are employed as well.

Current President Burns Hargis, has been a great president for the university including the successful  Branding Success campaign.
cons:
You are, for the most part, a State Employee of Oklahoma and in the Higher Education division. So while pay is competitive, there isn't much in the way of advancement. 

The other biggest problem is the structure. Each department is ran differently then other departments in the college. Each college is ran differently from other college, and each campus is ran differently then the others. IT is not centralized. You have one group that manages the software, but another group that is responsible for installing the software. etc.

Parking/Buildings: This one thing is what chaps me the most. Okstate spends money on remodeling a building, and then less than a few years tears it down and build something new. On top of that, the cost of parking (students, staff, and faculty have to pay for parking) has increased every year. But they are constantly removing parking lots to add green space.

pros: Great Benefits and flexible hours
cons: Poor Salary and minimum raises

pros:
Staff are generally nice and pleasant. 

Employment is very stable. If you don't mind very limited mobility, you could easily be employed here for decades. Positions are only removed after they are vacated instead of laying off staff, with the exception of all campus custodial staff being laid off in in 2014/2015.

There are health benefits and staff have access to Microsoft and Mac software for free.
cons:
Basic staff parking on campus is expensive ($120) and quickly dwindling due to campus building projects taking over the former staff parking lots. The only alternative if you want to park on campus is to purchase a spot in a parking garage, which is $185 - $300, depending on which garage you can get. 

Out-of-pocket insurance premiums have gone from $20 to $60 a month in about 3 years. Blue Cross Blue Shield OK went from negotiating contracts every three years to annually with OSU, which means a potential increase every year.

Compensation is significantly lower than other state entities. OSU has not had campus-wide cost of living increases since 2008.

Employees in many areas are spread incredibly thin. For example, there are only 6 IT staff in their tech support dept., and they are supposed to support all students, staff, and faculty on campus. Two of them are "executive support" and their only job is to serve the President's Office.

job_title: Temporary Research Scientist in Stillwater, OK
pros: You will get a lot of hands-on experience with an associated array of experimental procedures, machinery, and diction. Furthermore, your ability to assess problems and formulate solutions will be tested daily and encourage critical thinking. Being able to be resilient to failure and be able to bounce back with tenacity will take you far in research and grow your own self-drive. Being able to work as an individual and in a team setting will also be encouraged.
cons: Must be able to be self-sufficient in regard to figuring out experimental hurdles. It is the duty of the researcher to ask the hard questions as to why something worked or did not work. Some days in the lab may be long and others rather short, this is entirely dependent on the experiment and what needs to get done for the next day.

review_title: You can't help but bleed orange.
pros: The environment on the main campus is exciting. You can't help but get caught up in the spirit of all things orange. Naturally, depending on where you work on campus and who you work with with greatly determine how much you enjoy your job. Some departments are better than others but overall their is a "University Family" feel. Also - not taking advantage of tuition discounts is silly - especially if you hope to advance in your career. Holidays and vacation are generous. I now work in the "corporate" world and miss my holiday time!
cons: University politics within and between departments that are competitive with one another. Sometimes need to be reminded we're on the same team. It's a land grant university and depending on state budgets - will determine compensation. Don't expect to get rich and advancement opportunities are a challenge. You usually have to change roles or departments.

review_title: Run (Into the Ground) Like a Business
job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Stillwater, OK
pros:
Good department support for instructors
VAP pay is good, as are benefits
Classrooms well equipped with technology
cons:
OSU is the poster child for the things academia is doing wrong - lowering admissions standards to drive record enrollment, while at the same time cutting full-time faculty positions.  Fill the classrooms with wash-outs and hire low-cost adjuncts to teach them - who cares if they fail out, since you didn't invest much in teaching them?

Pair this with administrative bloat and an unlimited budget for the football team (while the academic departments have to beg for scraps, money-wise), and OSU rounds out the gamut of sucky stuff in academia.

Your department itself will likely be full of great people, and your work will be very enjoyable.  But the people above you are NOT working in your interest, or that of your students.

pros:
For most people, working for OSU feels like spending time with friends and getting paid for it. Whether you are working with students in a retail setting or working with professional administration personnel, everyone tends to be very friendly and relaxed. There are exceptions to this, but very few.

- Comfortable, friendly atmosphere
- Low stress, even during busy times
- Good benefits, good vacation allotment
- Easy to move between jobs or departments if your needs change, or if new positions become available
cons:
- Pay is well below market average
- Very few opportunities for promotion

job_title: Withheld By Request in Stillwater, OK
pros: Generally co-workers in the same area are easy to work with, as they are in the same boat.  However tons of backbiting and fighting for limited growth potential even with close coworkers in the event of a possible promotion.  Politics from the top down are rampant, but if you are fine with a political game, you will do well in this environment.
cons: Very  political, very poor pay.  Essentially no raises for the past three years.  Ambition is crushed and often (because they are good at the system) incompetence is rewarded.  This is probably typical of a state institution, but disappointing.

review_title: Should have done my homework before moving cross-country to work here.
pros: Benefits program okay, but sliding in the wrong direction.  Predictable work schedules.  Accessible management.  Stable employment.  Stillwater is a wonderful community to raise a family.
cons: Very low pay across the board for support staff.  Performance pay and bonuses abound for Athletics Dept, but nowhere else.  High parking fees for staff.  Pay freezes year after year after year. Very political atmosphere.  Campus in a constant state of destruction./construction.  OTRS package in complete financial ruin.  Unable to shift across into 401K.  No recognition for safety or innovative achievements.

job_title: Football Equipment Manager in Stillwater, OK
pros: Free Clothes; stand on sideline during games; get to know the football players; decent pay for college job (at least for the hours you GET to log)
cons: Horrible bosses and infrastructure; overworked on hours weekly with no overtime pay; random hours; you NEVER completely get away from work (ex. bosses always send texts, demand random hours whenever they decide with non warning); evenings are often too busy for other aspects of social life; road trips can be a major hassle while dealing with school work as well.

pros: Peers care about impact they are making, decent benefits
cons: Administration openly comments in staff meetings how staff are "expendable" and "replaceable."  Expect to work 70+ hour weeks and paid holidays without any comp time or extra pay because "in no way would we force you to work more than 40 hours and/or weekends, it was your choice to do so" even when assigned to after-hours events by managers.  They heavily play favorites, bully those who are successful, and apply HR policy when and how they choose.  Oklahoma is an at-will work state so there's no legal recourse to any of this either.  "Across the board" raises are not across the board, they are doled out at different rates to favorites.

review_title: Oklahoma State do you really want to work here?
pros: Medical, dental insurance coverage for the employee is good, work schedules can be flexible depending on the department. If you are interested in volunteering they have different projects for you to attend and help the community. A bus service is offered which can be used to travel from building to building.
cons: Medical insurance coverage for spouse/family is expensive, and you have a large deductible. Lack of parking space is an issue and you are charged a monthly fee for parking. Because you work for the state, raises are not given every year, but I guess that can happen at any job.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Stillwater, OK
pros: As a research assistant I gained a lot of hands on experience in the Heat Transfer and HVAC industry, working for Oklahoma State University. It also trained and prepared me for a full time job as a Mechanical Engineer
cons: Funding for projects is provided by outside companies, mine in particular were sponsored by ASHRAE and Dupont. And the renewal of these sponsorships depended on our performance as research engineers. Being research, results may need repetition of experiments. This puts a lot of pressure on us researchers

pros: I lucked in to having the only good manager that was there. He was the only positive part of working for OSU and the only reason I stayed as long as I did.
cons: No department knows what they're doing or cares to learn. It's very common (for employees and students needing help) to bounce from one department to another and another then back to the first when trying to find information. Pay is much lower than any other part time job on campus.

pros: You get to set your own hours, as you work from home. The pay is good for a student, and the flexible hours are incredibly nice for a student with a heavy class load. I work 16 hours a week and I am able to get it all done relatively easily.
cons: Some assigments will take a while to grade depending on the length of homework as well as the types of homework questions. I have graded for Calculus 2 and 3, Linear Algebra and Math functions. the upper level maths can take some time to grade as you have to review their work carefully to see that the theory is correctly applied or find exactly where they went wrong in their work.

pros: This was a great experience overall, I worked at the FAPC for 3 years and learned a great deal while working there. They were very flexible with my schedule and allowed me to set it as long as I stuck to it. I enjoyed being a part in the production of meat. I believe it's something that will allow me to always appreciate the animals life that was lost to give us the meat, as well as the hard work by the rancher to take care of the animal.
cons: Having to wear protective masks and safety glasses when cleaning with some of the chemicals that were very strong and meant for commercial use. Having to wake up early on a kill day.

pros:
1. Paid holidays off, ONLY if you're full-time
2. Free MS Windows & MS Office, etc. software downloads/upgrades
3. Student Services seems like a good department to work in
4. On-campus gym
cons: Seemingly uncaring/unprofessional leadership, responsibility level -to job title/pay ratio is extremely out of sync, lack of proper employee training, management that doesn't lead by example, unfair workload distribution, some inauthentic & immoral persons in positions of authority -thoroughly abusing power, & rarely available when high priority issues require their attention- then blaming/making lesser positions responsible- when having to answer to higher authority.

pros: Decent job security and friendly employees.  Tuition discounts for employees who want to continue their education.  Some flexibility in projects to work on for personal development and occasional training opportunities.  Working in education can be personally satisfying.
cons: Wages aren't competitive.  Failure to plan and highly reactive, unplanned work promotes stress and burnout.  Management seems disengaged and doesn't always provide adequate support or direction.  Many positions don't provide an avenue for promotion.  Annual pay increases, which are rare, fail to keep up with the cost of living.

pros: You are offered health care, including dental and eye.  Depending on your position, you have holidays off.
cons: There is very much a "good ol' boys" mentality here.  Difficult to fit in or advance unless you like to play politics.  The average pay is not that stellar, and there are very little raises given out.  The HR for the entire campus is very much a part of the politics game.  When your HR representative is unwilling to be unbiased and assist you, you know that things are messed up.

pros: The university has a family feel. A great deal of growth due to robust fundraising over the last ten years. Beautiful campus.
cons: They have a culture of grossly overworking faculty. There is a very strong "good ol' boy" culture. Many high level, male, leaders that many know are not excellent, but they are a part of the in group. There is a heavy focus on teaching with a lack of appreciation for research. Student body is quite low performing due to over emphasis on increasing numbers.

review_title: Payment vs. job requirements at Oklahoma State University
pros: It pays terribly. The benefits are good, but I have a Masters degree, have worked here 15 years and earn $43,745.88. I can't look for a public sector job because then I will not qualify for public service loan forgiveness.
cons: Some years we do not et raises (most actually) yet our parking permit prices are increased...

review_title: Great place to study and work
pros: The math department has a very healthy atmosphere, lovely administrative staff, an extremely capable chair, and a talented math education group. The students are not entitled, and generally understand the necessity and value of hard work.
cons: Several classrooms on campus are dilapidated or ill-planned. (However, some of the math building's classrooms are being remodeled this fall.) University Avenue desperately needs repaving. The IT department doesn't have the warm bodies to do repair dispatches, e.g. for printer malfunctions.

review_title: OSU is a great place to work!
pros: Good benefits (i.e. reduced tuition, if you don't need their insurance, the amount they would have paid for your insurance is put in a medical FSA, offices closed a week at the end of the year, fully paid retirement plan) -- my department is wonderful -- very relaxed and team atmosphere.
cons: Some departments can be highly political and nasty (not mine), some rules and regulations are forced by being a state entity, hard to find a parking space ;-)

review_title: Enjoyable and rewarding place to work.
pros: Many coworkers tend to stay on a long time, so there's low turnover.  Some factors could be nice benefits and generous time off as well as a good work environment.  Employees get tuition discounts, which is useful if you're working towards a degree.  Also, it's rewarding to work in an industry where you know you're helping people improve their lives.
cons: The economic downturn has decreased revenue and forced OSU to conserve money, which has cut into raises and other opportunities.  In some fields the salaries seem to be on the low side.

pros: Great work environment, benefits, and organization! Oklahoma State University allows you to grow into your position and preferes the "cowboy family" when other opportunities open up within the university!
cons: What you get out of working for OSU is what you put in, some people need more structure and hard/line items to succeed to their full potential. You will rise to the top if you are willing to work for it. There are so many potentials and positive things for your career here. If you're willing to work, working here should be a top consideration for you and your family!

pros: I worked as a Peer Mentor for SSB for one semester and it was a rewarding opportunity. I got to help freshman students transition into the college life while serving as a role model and academic resource.
cons: As a Peer Mentor I was assigned to a class section with one other Peer Mentor and an Academic Advisor. I downside to this was that each section did things a little bit differently depending on the advisor that was in charge. The advisors liked to have feedback on the peer mentoring program as a whole but it was hard to give feedback when each section was done differently.

review_title: GTA at the Edmon Low Library in Research and Learning Services
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Stillwater, OK
pros: This was a great job! It provided me with a tuition waiver that waived both out-of-state and in-state tuition (I am an out-of-state student) so that I only had to pay fees.  It provided me with teaching experience for someone without a teaching background or prior experience. It was an easy, flexible job with really great people. The librarians are fun and they really care about student success. My boss was flexible about my class schedule. It was a really great experience all around.
cons: I don't have any cons for this job. It was awesome.

pros: You can learn a lot different methods. Good time to learn things which you never did before. You can take courses as well to study. This is sometimes hard to explain to advisor since you would need to be in lab. This could be a good opportunity to learn how to write the grants and to write more publications.
cons: If you work with cells, commonly you will be working on Sat./Sun as well. You may not have clear information from advisor about your vacation time, although you would be working extended hours anyway. Low pay. Commonly not recommended path, to learn more.

job_title: Research Assistant/Teacher's Assistant in Stillwater, OK
pros:
Environment is rarely uncomfortably high pressure
The professors are helpful and patient
Good facilities located in close proximity
Lots of independence
cons:
A little too relaxed day-to-day, causing widespread lack of productivity
Typical tendency to keep grad students around as long as possible before granting degrees
Teaching lab sections can be a pain due to poor teaching materials and equipment

review_title: Great place, great people! ...if you get in a good department
job_title: Administrative Support Specialist I in Stillwater, OK
pros: Once you're in, you're in. Once passed your preliminary period, it is hard to get fired which does encourage employee morale.
cons: If you're on campus, the parking is a nightmare. Benefits are not that great, except for the week off at Christmas (if your department takes it!)

review_title: Great people, great benefits, great town to live in!
pros: Stillwater is a great town to live in. 1 hour away from two major cities (OKC and Tulsa). OSU offers great benefits. The people who work at OSU are friendly, competent and its a very fun and family like atmosphere (at least where I worked). Campus is beautiful, lots of dining options.
cons: Pay isn't always the best, considering they're a government agency and have limited funding. Parking can be hard to find. Things move slow in higher education.

review_title: Challenging work, great atmosphere - a place to grow
pros:
I've held multi-year positions in corporate, startup, and educational environments. Each has their positives and negatives, but I've long searched for a place that could strike a balance between the three. I found that blend in PointSource: the maturity of senior management from a corporate environment; the forward thinking and research aspects of an educational institution; and the lively, fast-paced flow of a startup culture challenging itself each day. 

Though the company's focus is on mobile application development, our collective experience and consistent success leads to us being pulled in to help improve other aspects of a company's infrastructure. This creates a hotbed of new and challenging projects that spawn off one another and regularly let a developer, architect, and team lead stretch their talents and skills.

Other items of note:
*There are an assortment of short and long terms projects. When one finishes, people often move to another project for either the same or a different client. Different projects use different technologies to match the clients' needs, so people do pick up new concepts and environments.

*The ability to collaborate and communicate is a must. Team members - from leads, to architects, to backend/frontend developers, designers, so on and so forth - everybody works together in a fast paced manner to complete tasks, sprints, and projects.

*Agile methodologies are used to provide rapid, iterative deployments for our clients to work with. No waterfall.

*Career growth. In addition to having the opportunity to learn new technologies, the development manager works with each employee to discover what they want to do, career wise, and helps them move toward it.

*While occasional long hours are necessary, most weeks see only 40-50 hour work weeks with a standard 8-4/9-5 work day.

*People are encouraged to discuss their solutions to problems, and learn what they can from other team members.
cons:
Many of my friends are in computing technology, medical, or other big business. Inevitably, when talking about our work, they ask about the negatives. At first, I didn't have anything to offer because I couldn't find any. That's when I discovered that there are no cons for me because the company fits my personality.

Therefore if the following fit your personality, you are *NOT* likely to enjoy working at PointSource:

*Enjoy working alone without needing to communicate with coworkers or discuss potential solutions with one another.

*Enjoy working on multi-year waterfall based projects that provide lengthy amounts of 'downtime' until everything comes down to the wire.

*Enjoy working on tech bases that don't change, or grow, and don't want to learn new technologies or grow your career.

review_title: Satisfaction Depends on What You're Willing to Overlook
pros: Single insurance fully paid. Extra perks like discounts @ local businesses nice, too. Holidays off and break schedule were great benefits, as well.
cons: You paid for what you got! I worked in a department that had a huge sense of entitlement. Always a way to get around University regulations, and sometimes the law, but it was most often overlooked or ignored.

review_title: Oklahoma State University is a safe and educational place to work
pros: Oklahoma State University offers a good work life balance. The work schedule allows for quality time with family. I enjoy interacting with students and participating in their development.
cons: Not much room for growth for most faculty. Most of the employees are making average to below average wages and they are not able to really excel financially.

pros: I feel its so rewarding! Most student care and ask questions. Lab always leaves me with a positive feeling. Plus I relearn all the basic geo material, and learn how to present weekly.
cons: To be a teaching assistant, I have a two hour lab, and weekly one hour lab prep meeting, two hour office hours throughout the week, and the other prep time to get everything arranged. It is definitely a time commitment. I almost forgot, all the time to grade each lab and enter grades. That takes a while too. But worth it!

review_title: Wonderful Entry Level & Perfect for Furthering Education
pros: I love working in an office setting, the pay is decent, wonderful benefits, and it is your normal 8-5 job. Great job if you're thinking of furthering your education.
cons: The workload sometimes seems to double in my department with no real compensation. Office moral is at a low and even seems non existent. Certain areas in the department are not treated the same as other areas.

cons: Micromanagement in nearly every department. You are restricted to a low amount of hours and most jobs do not pay much over minimum wage. (Could be a pro if you are only wanting to work a low amount of hours each week)

pros: Great community (not overly crowded but still many options for things to do); Nice campus; Free workout facility for faculty (w/ affordable options for family); great opportunities for children; Was walking and passed by the president leaving his office building - he was very friendly
cons: Earthquakes!; Food options are heavily tilted towards chains (of course, Eskimo Joe's is a local favorite!); Expensive in spite of the smaller community; my building is old and decrepit; University budget is heavily tied to oil (so not a good time right now, circa 2015)

review_title: Great people and excellent work environment.

State worker gets you a lot of benefits. As a Math Tutor in MLSC, I used to get paid $13/hour.
P.S. MLSC stands for Mathematics Learning and Success Center

The only thing which was tough is to get shift covers, especially during exams week. You have to be good at managing your time to pass this huddle.

cons: Employees in this department do not want to work but would like a pay check every two weeks. They have Union representation so it makes it just that harder to get people who don't want to work out of the hospital. Basically you have to write an encyclopedia to get the bad workers out, which in turn makes it hard on the management team to do their job.

pros: It was a great atmosphere, friendly co-workers and team leads.  The scheduling was pretty laid back, and throughout the year never went on tour more than twice a week.

Lots of Negativity, at least within the Student Union and the Dining Department. Raises only came around every 4 years or so and were not guaranteed when approved.

pros: The best reason to work for OSU is the patients. I love my patients (most of them, anyway!)
